alert.note: Alert for Central Highlands; Chaves County Plains; Curry County; De Baca County; East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Eastern Lincoln County; Eastern San Miguel County; Estancia Valley; Far Northeast Highlands; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Guadalupe County; Harding County; Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass; Northeast Highlands; Quay County; Roosevelt County; Sandia, Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; South Central Highlands; South Central Mountains; Southwest Chaves County; Union County (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued December 19 at 7:38AM MST by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...ARCTIC FRONT TO BRING FRIGID TEMPERATURES TO EASTERN NEW MEXICO THURSDAY... After mostly seasonal temperatures across eastern New Mexico on Wednesday, drastic changes are expected Wednesday night into Thursday as a blast of cold, Arctic air overtakes the area. Temperatures will be absolutely frigid across the northeastern corner of the state Thursday with many locations observing daytime highs in the single digits and teens. Daytime highs in east central portions of the state will not be quite as harsh, but still quite cold with temperatures struggling to make it into the 20`s and low 30`s Thursday afternoon. Temperatures will likely remain below freezing for many eastern locations from late Wednesday night through Saturday morning. In addition to the cold temperatures, very gusty winds from the north and northeast will create dangerously low wind chills that will plummet below zero across a large portion of eastern New Mexico late Wednesday night through Thursday night. In fact, wind chills in northeastern parts of the state may fall between -25 to -35 degrees, producing a high risk for frostbite and hypothermia to anyone outdoors. The time to prepare is now! Take action and ensure your home and vehicles are all winterized. Inspect and clean your fireplace and chimney, promptly perform any necessary maintenance on your furnace, and ensure you have a working carbon monoxide detector with extra batteries. Make sure your pets and any livestock have adequate shelter from the wind and cold temperatures, and wrap or insulate any outdoor plumbing fixtures. Remain tuned into the latest weather forecast and statements at weather.gov/abq or through your preferred media outlet.
